newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Cocoa-Indonesian cocoa crop harvest on target.
newsitem.headline: Cocoa-Indonesian cocoa crop harvest on target.

text.p: Indonesia's cocoa harvest for this year is on target, industry officials said on Wednesday.

Siswoputranto, executive director of the Indonesian Cocoa Association (ICA), told Reuters after a meeting with officials of the Central Statistics Bureau that a decision had been taken not to revise cocoa crop forecasts.
"The forecast still remains the same at 290,000 tonnes for all of Indonesia in 1996," Siswoputranto said.
Traders said cocoa prices in Ujung Pandang, the trading centre for the key cocoa growing area of Sulawesi, were higher at around 2,825 rupiah/kg from about 2,775 rupiah/kg two weeks ago.

They said the increase was due to stronger foreign demand and rising overseas prices. Cocoa futures in New York ended sharply higher on Tuesday after late speculative buying saw the commodity end $21 up at $1,430 a tonne.
Siswoputranto said firm figures were not yet available for the amount of arrivals but he estimated about 120,000 tonnes of cocoa had already been harvested this year.
"So far there have been no problems and we estimate a normal production," he said.
There had been some concerns in the industry that rains in the key growing area of Sulawesi would delay the peak harvest season in September-October.
Siswoputranto also said that fears that the cocoa crop in Central Java would be distrupted by the increasing volcanic activity of Mount Merapi near Yogyakarta were unfounded.
"An eruption would have no effect because the growing areas are south of Yogyakarta," he said.
